speakers.text: The vast majority of the bondholders settled with Argentina.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: If you win on the Alderson Reporting Company categorical question that's presented here, do you think it's still open to Argentina to go back to the district court and to say, modify your ruling for this or that privilege reason or because the order is overinclusive or any of these more prudential considerations.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What exactly would a district judge do in those circumstances?  So you -- Argentina says this, this is military property.  And what would the judge inquire?  What would the judge do before deciding whether to allow discovery of something like that?  Would it look -- would it look to the law of the country where the property is located?  Would it make some kind of factual inquiry as to whether it really is military?  What would go on?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Does the waiver extend to military property?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, then the waiver just restates the immunity that's provided in the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: How does it go beyond that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But not as to military property.  So how do I know how far the waiver extends?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I'm asking whether or not the waiver extends to Argentine military property.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Does it waive immunity as to a consular residence or an embassy building?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. Mr. Blackman, you have 3 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
